dt: {bc}the dried root of a European leguminous plant ({it}Glycyrrhiza glabra{/it}) with pinnate leaves and spikes of blue flowers
{bc}an extract of this used especially in medicine, liquors, and confectionery
{bc}a candy flavored with licorice or a substitute (such as anise)

et: Middle English {it}licorice{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}licoris{/it}, from Late Latin {it}liquiritia{/it}, alteration of Latin {it}glycyrrhiza{/it}, from Greek {it}glykyrrhiza{/it}, from {it}glykys{/it} sweet + {it}rhiza{/it} root {ma}{mat|dulcet|}, {mat|root|}{/ma}
shortdef: the dried root of a European leguminous plant (Glycyrrhiza glabra) with pinnate leaves and spikes of blue flowers; also : an extract of this used especially in medicine, liquors, and confectionery
a candy flavored with licorice or a substitute (such as anise)
a plant yielding licorice; also : a related plant

dt: {bc}a tropical twining herb ({it}Abrus precatorius{/it}) of the legume family that bears jequirity beans and has a root used as a substitute for licorice

shortdef: a tropical twining herb (Abrus precatorius) of the legume family that bears jequirity beans and has a root used as a substitute for licorice —called also Indian licorice, jequirity bean
